SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. He attributes these symptoms to the change in seasons and recent home construction projects. The patient has been experiencing these symptoms for about five weeks. He denies fever, chills, and significant shortness of breath. He reports a slight cough and occasional chest cramps that resolve within an hour. The patient's diet has been off due to kitchen renovations, leading to eating out more frequently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue and lightheadedness. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: Positive bloating. No significant shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Positive slight cough. No significant wheezing or dyspnea.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.

Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical examination and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor weight daily and report any significant weight gain or shortness of breath. Order a follow-up echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevated readings through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She reports that she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and had a stumble, twisting her knee as she tried to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stressing of the leg. Normal sensation is present. No pain in the calves.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but everything else appears to be lined up properly.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide her with crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for re-evaluation, and if not improved, we will obtain an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, and it has been stiff ever since. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat without significant relief. He experienced tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, the patient admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He is taking metformin for his diabetes. For his hypertension, he is monitoring his blood pressure readings at home during the week and taking his medication. He has early arthritis in his knee, which gets aggravated occasionally.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Endorses occasional knee pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot, resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

X-ray lumbar spine, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: If he continues to have pain, we will obtain an MRI for further evaluation.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer him to physical therapy to work on strengthening the area.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: He has been compliant with metformin and dietary modifications, but his recent hemoglobin A1c was 8.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: His blood pressure readings run a little high, and his blood pressure was elevated in the office today.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg once daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing a good job monitoring his knee and does not require further workup at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam, follow-up of depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam. The patient reports a tough spring due to pollen and moving his daughter to college. He has been managing his depression with Prozac and has not had any incidents recently. He struggles with hypertension and admits to occasionally forgetting to take his Norvasc on weekends.

Regarding his prior lobectomy, he reports no significant issues with shortness of breath, except during high heat and pollen season. He experiences shortness of breath with exertion while running 4-5 miles daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.
• Head and Neck: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Refill prescription for Prozac 20 mg daily.

2. Prior lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly, and breathing function is fine.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-controlled in the office.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication (Norvasc).

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls. The incident occurred on Sunday.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Appendectomy at age 18
Constipation

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and everything lines up well.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for further evaluation. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia, who presents today for evaluation and management. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, feverishness, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She has been anemic since she was 13 years old and had a hysterectomy in 1996. She denies any recent gastrointestinal bleeding or other symptoms that may suggest a source of blood loss.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue, feverishness, and chills.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Endorses headaches.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Normal physical exam without any significant findings.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia, who presents today for evaluation and management.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been dealing with anemia for a long time, and the cause is still unknown. She denies any recent gastrointestinal bleeding or other symptoms that may suggest a source of blood loss.
• Additional Testing: We will schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If these tests are inconclusive, a capsule endoscopy will be considered.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer her to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.
• Medical Treatment: The patient is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12. We advised her to continue taking her iron pills with orange juice for better absorption and to recheck her CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate levels in 8-12 weeks.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward, a 52-year-old male, presents to the clinic for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. He initially presented to his primary care provider, Dr. Henry Howard, on 3/1/21, complaining of worsening headaches over the past few months. The patient denies any history of headaches. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where a pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, UH, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results being normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size, and no other abnormalities are noted.

The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache, with a gradual onset and worsening over the past three months. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other symptoms, such as feeling sick, fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has noticed bumping into door frames recently.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Unremarkable.

Social
Computer programmer, married for 25 years, recently bought a small house. Non-smoker, non-drinker, and no recreational drug use.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma.

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule transsphenoidal surgery to remove the pituitary adenoma and decompress the optic chiasm.
3. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery to assess improvement.
4. Send the removed adenoma to pathology for diagnosis confirmation.

The patient is informed of the risks associated with anesthesia and surgery, including infection, need for further surgery, wound issues, seizure, stroke, permanent numbness, weakness, difficulty speaking, or even death. The patient agrees to proceed with the surgery. The surgery scheduler will set up appointments for the visual field test and surgery.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents as a new patient with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. The patient reports having chest pain for four days in early October 2020, which resolved on its own. She has not had any chest pain since then. The pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. The patient experienced difficulty swallowing during this time, which has also resolved. She denies any abdominal pain and reports normal bowel movements. The patient underwent gallbladder removal several years ago.

ER visit in October 2020 revealed normal cardiac workup, including EKG and blood tests. The patient was referred for possible GI issues.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen
• Examination of Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No pain or tenderness in the lower abdomen.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 53-year-old female who presents with a history of chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020. Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal issues, and anxiety. The patient reported a stressful job transition around the time of the chest pain, which may have contributed to her symptoms.

Given that the patient has been asymptomatic for three months, the decision was made to hold off on an EGD and continue to monitor for any additional symptoms. The patient will call the office if any episodes of pain or other concerning symptoms occur, at which point an EGD may be scheduled. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidneys due to Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of her kidneys. She is a twin, born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, with a birth weight of 4 pounds, 8 ounces. She has had issues with feeding and temperature regulation in the past, as well as gastroesophageal reflux. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. She is also scheduled to start speech therapy soon. Katherine has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned the possibility of kidney anomalies in patients with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Well-nourished, slightly fussy during examination.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Normal.
• Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
• Respiratory: Normal lung sounds.
• Gastrointestinal: History of gastroesophageal reflux.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of lower extremities and arms.
• Neurological: Developmental delays, including not walking independently yet.
• Ophthalmologic: Small appearing eyes.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
• Respiratory: Normal lung sounds.
• Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended.
• Extremities: Mild hypotonia of lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of her kidneys due to the potential for congenital anomalies associated with her syndrome.

• Kidney Evaluation: We will obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for any abnormalities. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up will be needed. If there are abnormalities, we will determine the next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

Patient Agreements: The patient's family understands and agrees with the recommended medical evaluation plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her right arm. She reports that her wrist started to hurt immediately and became swollen. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ACE wrap, and taking ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists. The patient denies any previous injuries to her right arm. She reports some tingling in her fingers but is still able to feel them.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Reports tingling in fingers but denies numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head/Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
CV: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower leg edema, palpable pulses.
Right Wrist: Obvious swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness on palpation, pain on flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. Able to make a fist but not tightly. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended conservative treatment initially with a brace for her right wrist. The patient will be scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. She will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. Post-surgery, the patient will be referred to physical therapy for rehabilitation. The patient will follow up in one month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to wear the brace for six weeks and attend physical therapy as recommended. If her pain does not improve or worsens, she will contact the office for further evaluation.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, managed with 20 mg Lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports working on his property when the injury occurred.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, belly pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation of the medial aspect. Edema and effusion present. No pain on the lateral aspect.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. These reveal no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient reports slipping and falling, resulting in knee pain and swelling.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and inflammation. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Advise the patient to elevate and rest the leg, avoiding strenuous activities.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and reports difficulty managing diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue 20 mg Lisinopril for blood pressure management. Refer the patient to a nutritionist for dietary counseling.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects it may be related. The patient states he is very active and has experienced occasional aches and pains before that usually resolve with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant and worsens when pressure is applied, such as when lying on the shoulder. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to nearly fall. She describes the pain as internal and involving the whole kneecap. The pain comes and goes quickly, and she has not experienced any popping sensation or previous injury to the knee. The patient denies taking any medications for pain, as it does not last long. She is concerned about participating in line dancing during an upcoming trip due to her knee instability.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports controlled blood pressure with medication.

Endocrine: Reports slightly elevated morning blood sugars, taking metformin.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation of the left medial knee. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension, controlled with medication.
3. Diabetes mellitus, taking metformin.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the surrounding muscles.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1C and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to metformin dosage. Encourage the patient to continue taking metformin as prescribed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Minimal cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good family support and positive interactions with nursing staff and office.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports minimal dry cough and no shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Reports sore throat but no difficulty swallowing or eating.
Psychiatric: Patient reports feeling emotionally and mentally strong.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Face
- Examination: No pain to palpation of the frontal or maxillary sinuses.

Neck
- General Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide and radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen and radiation therapy at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of therapy to assess for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and bilateral crackles on lung exam are likely due to radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat is likely due to inflammation in the esophagus from radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to help with pain relief and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient was referred by their primary care physician due to a low immunoglobulin A level found during a recent physical examination. Patient reports frequent colds during the winter months that tend to linger but is unsure if this is more than usual.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes - recently started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies. Family is generally healthy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient recently traveled to Zambia. Family owns a donut shop.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal infections or frequent diarrhea.

VITALS

Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY DATA

Low Immunoglobulin A level.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low Immunoglobulin A level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work is consistent with an IgA deficiency, which is a common immunodeficiency. Most people with this deficiency live normal lives, but some may experience frequent respiratory, sinus, or abdominal infections. In this patient's case, there is a low likelihood of other immunodeficiencies.
- Additional Testing: Order blood work to check for other antibodies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Explained the nature of IgA deficiency and advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control, as well as any changes in their abdominal tract. Informed the patient to notify healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they require blood products in the future.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended assessment and plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. His pain is localized to the medial aspect of his elbow and can radiate down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The pain is rated as 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient reports that he has been doing a lot of pottery during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. No pain with supination. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the following plan for his current symptoms:
1. Rest the right elbow and wear a sling while awake.
2. Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week.
4. Hold off on pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
5. Follow-up appointment in one week to evaluate progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after falling and experiencing chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily, but admits to missing doses occasionally.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during recent fall.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Lung Examination: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed dietary modifications as noted above.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes in waves. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain relief, but it has not been effective. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. He has a history of kidney stones and his father also had kidney stones.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and nausea.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. The patient may continue to take Tylenol for any breakthrough pain.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to use when urinating to catch the stone for further analysis.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to check on the patient's progress. If symptoms have not improved, discuss further treatment options including lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient should contact the doctor if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The ulcer initially presented as a blister with stinging and burning sensations. Over time, the ulcer worsened, developing a foul smell, yellow drainage, and blackened edges. The patient also reports cramping in his calf muscle and a red streak extending from his ankle to his calf. He has been on antibiotics for 6 days, with 2-3 days remaining in the course. The patient has experienced fever, chills, and difficulty breathing in recent days.

The patient's diabetes has been well-controlled with an A1c of 6.7 for the past two years. However, he reports that his blood sugars have been trending higher in the past few weeks, with some readings in the 300-400 range and one spike at 500-600.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient enjoys hiking and recently hiked a new trail with his wife. He wears diabetic shoes and inserts, which he changes every 3-4 months.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

Foot: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythemia, and odor. No bony exposure. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Vascular: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses.
No pain upon pressing the affected area of the wound.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer
2. Diabetes
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

The patient will undergo a debridement in the office today, and a culture will be taken to determine if a change in antibiotic therapy is necessary. The patient will continue his current antibiotic course for the remaining 2-3 days. An arterial ultrasound will be ordered to assess blood supply to the wound. The patient will be advised to closely monitor his blood sugars and follow up with his endocrinologist to maintain his A1c below 7. The patient will be seen again in 7 days for a follow-up evaluation.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors and recently went hunting. He noticed a tick bite on his right knee over a week ago, which has been burning and causing discomfort.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Reports arthritic pain, but no new joint pain since tick bite.
Neurological: Reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: On lisinopril 20 mg daily.
Diabetes: On metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not reported
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee.
Skin: Erythema, edema, and bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Suspected Lyme disease due to tick bite and bull's-eye rash.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension.
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Order hemoglobin A1C to assess long-term blood sugar control.
- Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
